articles.headline: In Japan, a Robust Yen Undermines the Markets
articles.snippet: The yen, which surged as much as 10 percent against the dollar last week, is generating high-level anxiety.
articles.abstract: The yen, which surged as much as 10 percent against the dollar last week, is generating high-level anxiety.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Tumbling stock markets and falling currencies are causing global concern, but the Japanese yen is generating high anxiety for rising too much. The yen surged as much as 10 percent against the dollar last week. In the last month, it has gained an astounding 34 percent against the euro.

articles.headline: Microsoft Plans ‘Cloud’ Operating System
articles.snippet: The company said the system would manage the relationship between software inside the computer and on the Web.
articles.abstract: The company said the system would manage the relationship between software inside the computer and on the Web.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Looking for growth in new markets where it is increasingly being bypassed, Microsoft said Monday that late next year it would begin offering a new “cloud” operating system that would manage the relationship between software inside the computer and on the Web, where data and services are becoming increasingly centralized.

articles.headline: Hardships Past Haunt Europe’s Search for Financial Safety
articles.snippet: While their savings and retirements have been less exposed to stock market woes, history has taught Europeans that situations can go from bad to worse in no time.
articles.abstract: While their savings and retirements have been less exposed to stock market woes, history has taught Europeans that situations can go from bad to worse in no time.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I haven’t forgotten history,” says Gert Heinz, a tax adviser in Munich. “If you depend on paper money you can lose everything. We’ve learned that the hard way after two world wars.”

articles.headline: Finding a Gold Mine in Digital Ditties
articles.snippet: Joel Moss Levinson has won over $200,000 in money and prizes for his homemade corporate commercials.
articles.abstract: Joel Moss Levinson has won over $200,000 in money and prizes for his homemade corporate commercials.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joel Moss Levinson always knew he had a calling in life. But it took cheap video cameras, YouTube and some desperate corporations to show him what it was.

articles.headline: Fractures in Iraq City as Kurds and Baghdad Vie
articles.snippet: American commanders worry that the Shiite-led government’s push to squeeze Kurdish units out of the Iraqi Army in Mosul could lead to confrontation.
articles.abstract: American commanders worry that the Shiite-led government’s push to squeeze Kurdish units out of the Iraqi Army in Mosul could lead to confrontation.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSUL, Iraq  A new Iraqi military offensive is under way in this still violent northern city, but the worry is not only the insurgents who remain strong here. American commanders are increasingly concerned that Mosul could degenerate into a larger battleground over the fragile Iraqi state itself.

articles.headline: Google’s Green Agenda Could Pay Off
articles.snippet: The Internet search giant is increasingly looking to the energy sector as a potential business opportunity.
articles.abstract: The Internet search giant is increasingly looking to the energy sector as a potential business opportunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Google, the Internet search and advertising giant, is increasingly looking to the energy sector as a potential business opportunity.

articles.headline: G.M. Speeds Hat in Hand to Treasury
articles.snippet: The automaker is lobbying hard for a government rescue that would finance a merger with Chrysler, arguing that its fate should not mimic that of Lehman Brothers.
articles.abstract: The automaker is lobbying hard for a government rescue that would finance a merger with Chrysler, arguing that its fate should not mimic that of Lehman Brothers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is General Motors too big to fail?

articles.headline: After I Win ... Er, Make That, if I Am Elected
articles.snippet: The candidates have slipped a few times into the “when I’m president” construction, but are usually more careful.
articles.abstract: The candidates have slipped a few times into the “when I’m president” construction, but are usually more careful.
articles.lead_paragraph: MESILLA, N.M.  Senators Barack Obama and John McCain have been ever vigilant in recent days for signs of January Fever.

articles.headline: White House Explores Aid for Auto Deal
articles.snippet: The Bush administration is examining a range of options to spur a merger between General Motors and Chrysler, government officials said.
articles.abstract: The Bush administration is examining a range of options to spur a merger between General Motors and Chrysler, government officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration is examining a range of options for providing emergency financial help to spur a merger between General Motors and Chrysler, according to government officials.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Even as Dow Soars 11%, Skeptics Lurk
articles.snippet: Markets surged on bargain-hunting, raising the question of whether stocks have fallen enough to reflect the declines in profits that would accompany a potentially long recession.
articles.abstract: Markets surged on bargain-hunting, raising the question of whether stocks have fallen enough to reflect the declines in profits that would accompany a potentially long recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: A tug of war is in full swing on Wall Street and those pulling for stocks came out way ahead on Tuesday for the first time in a while.

articles.headline: Google Settles Suit Over Book-Scanning
articles.snippet: Google agreed to pay $125 million to settle two copyright lawsuits by book authors and publishers over its book-scanning project.
articles.abstract: Google agreed to pay $125 million to settle two copyright lawsuits by book authors and publishers over its book-scanning project.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Settling a legal battle, Google reached an agreement with book publishers and authors that clears the way for both sides to more easily profit from digital versions of printed books.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Motoko Rich
